Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Multi-Material 3D Printing of Personalized Medical Simulation Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop the necessary technology and manufacturing workflows to provide medical professionals with extremely realistic physical models of tissues and organs. The models will be manufactured rapidly (within a few hours), inexpensively, and on-demand. They will be patient-specific based on the patient?s CT and MRI scan data. This will have profound implications on the planning of complex medical procedures such as tumor removal and will enable medical professionals and their teams to practice patient-specific surgical scenarios. This will improve surgical outcome, generate efficiencies in the operating room and decrease medical errors which, by some accounts, are the third largest cause of death in the United States. The ability to 3D print realistic human organ models will also provide medical students with a way to practice medical procedures with a wide degree of diversity. This will accelerate the learning rate and expand the breadth of training experiences. Similarly, the models will provide a way for medical professionals to practice rare, high-risk procedures on-demand. The proposed 3D models will become a central part of the medical simulation toolbox and will enable a new generation of surgical planning and education.

The ability to manufacture extremely realistic physical models rapidly, inexpensively, and on-demand relies on a novel multimaterial additive manufacturing process with a closed-feedback loop enabled by machine vision. This new process manufactures objects layer by layer, each layer made from a discrete set of elements, where each element is built from one material from a pallette of materials. The use of the closed-feedback loop system allows incorporating both liquids and solids with a wide range of mechanical and appearance properties. The development of a material palette that is necessary to mimic properties of real tissues will be a crucial part of the project. This material palette will be expanded by spatially combining base materials into composite structures. The second main thrust of the project relies on a software design workflow that translates geometric and material specifications describing a simulation model (e.g., an organ or a tissue) into multimaterial volumetric data. The volumetric data will be used as input to the multimaterial printing platform. The new design workflow requires development of modeling approaches that go beyond traditional, boundary-based CAD representations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive manufacturing has the potential to transform manufacturing. Despite substantial progress over the past three decades, a number of challenges remain that limit its usefulness. Polymer 3D printing in particular suffers from low availability of industrially relevant materials. Inkbit seeks to solve this problem, by pioneering the use of machine vision to enable more accurate, more reliable printing, with a much broader range of materials. By endowing 3D printers with eyes and brains, our machines can deal with challenging materials and print parts that are ready for use, not just prototypes.

While performing the work proposed in this Phase I Award, titled ?Multi-Material 3D Printing of Personalized Medical Simulation Models,? Inkbit discovered a need for an improved selection of materials with thermal and mechanical properties capable of meeting the performance requirements expected by industrial applications. Following customer interviews, the project scope was then re-focused on improving materials performance, making use of Inkbit?s contact-less inkjet printing platform. Contact-less inkjet printing allows for an expanded portfolio of photopolymer resins by eliminating the failure-prone planarization mechanism that is used in traditional inkjet printing systems. As a result, Inkbit has developed printable photopolymer systems with thermal and mechanical performance on-par with common engineering plastics.

Figure 1 shows a complex fluid manifold printed from a high temperature material. The manifold has multiple orifices and fine internal features less than 1 mm in size. Typical high temperature photopolymers compatible with inkjet printing do not exceed heat deflection temperatures of 100 ?C and can exhibit large degrees of warping. This rigid material has a heat deflection temperature of 168 ?C and has high dimensional stability, making it useful for a wide range of applications requiring high stiffness and temperature resistance. Example use cases are electrical connectors, cooling components, and automotive brackets and connectors.

 

During the course of this project we have developed high performance elastomers with significantly higher mechanical properties (such as rebound, elongation at break, and tensile strength) than those of commercially available elastomer photopolymers. This was accomplished through synthesis of customized monomers intended for inkjet formulations.  An example of these materials is illustrated in Figure 2, which compares the elongation at break of our materials to the best commercially available. Ours elongates over 900% prior to failure at 4 MPa. This is a substantial improvement over inkjet-compatible elastomers based on commercial resins, which typically have poor rebound, elongation, and tensile strength.

 

We have also developed biocompatible rigid and elastomeric materials that have passed ISO 10993-5/10/11 testing standards, intended for light-duty medical applications such as skin contact and limited mucosal contact. Additionally, these materials are mutually compatible and can be printed side-by-side, to enable multi-material parts with varied mechanical properties throughout the geometry. An example multi-material dental guide with a rigid guide section and soft gum contact section is pictured below.

 

Because of the vision system integrated into our 3D printer, that allows us to monitor material behavior in real-time during the print, we are in a unique position to develop novel engineering-grade materials to address applications across a wide range of industries such as apparel, defense, automotive, healthcare, and others where current additive manufacturing materials are inadequate for meeting end-use requirements.
